nodes.text: Contact comfort, rather than nursing or food-related drive reduction, is the primary variable underlying the formation and persistence of infant affectional bonds
Prevailing psychological theory holds that affection is a derived drive produced by association of the mother with primary drive reduction (hunger, thirst, pain, sex)

Human neonates are limited experimental subjects for precise analysis of early affectional variables; neonatal rhesus macaque monkeys are a suitable model because they are more mature at birth and show similar developmental sequences

Constructed two mother surrogates: a soft, warm cloth-covered terry cloth surrogate providing contact comfort plus heat and a wire-mesh surrogate providing posture and nursing support but minimal contact comfort

Dual-mother experiment: eight newborn monkeys were raised with both cloth and wire surrogates; for four the cloth mother lactated and wire did not, and for four the reverse; infants could freely contact either mother and time on each was recorded automatically
Control groups included infants raised on a single wire mother, a single cloth mother, and a group never exposed to any surrogate until later introduction

Result: Infants overwhelmingly preferred the cloth surrogate over the wire surrogate regardless of which surrogate provided milk; contact comfort dominated nursing in choice behavior during first 14 days and across 165 days

Result: No differences in milk intake or weight gain between single-cloth and single-wire reared groups, but wire-mother infants had softer stools suggesting psychosomatic effects; wire mother is biologically adequate but psychologically inept
Evidence from fear tests: when presented with fear stimuli in presence of both surrogates infants consistently sought the cloth mother as a haven of safety regardless of which provided nursing

Evidence from open-field tests: cloth surrogate served as a secure base for exploration, lowering emotionality scores and enabling return-to-mother exploratory pattern; absence of mother increased freezing and distress behaviors

Result from modified Butler box visual exploration tests: infants raised with surrogates showed strong visual preference and responding to the cloth mother comparable to another infant and greater than to a wire mother or empty box; this was independent of nursing condition

Result: Control infants introduced to cloth and wire surrogates at 250 days initially showed fear and avoidance but within days developed strong attachment to the cloth mother, though peak contact time was lower than infants mothered from birth

Retention and longitudinal evidence: preference for cloth mother persisted across long retention intervals (up to 185 days tested), showing high resistance to extinction and stable affectional bonds despite infrequent contact reinforcement

Conclusion: Contact comfort is a fundamental affectional variable that motivates attachment, security seeking, and exploration patterns in infant macaques and can override food-based explanations of attachment

Limitation and future directions: generalization to humans requires caution; other variables (postural support, rocking, arms, maternal sounds, visual face features, imprinting) may also contribute and should be systematically tested
